data.text: What Makes a Bikepacking Tent Different from a Backpacking Tent?
What makes a bikepacking tent different than a backpacking tent? Just the 12‚Äù pole sections?
Not a whole lot. Just look at size, weight and pack size.
data.author: Lee Hollenbeck

data.text: Marketing makes the difference.
data.author: Timo Everaers

data.text: Yeah mostly pole section size
data.author: Seth Brewer

data.text: The only thing is the 12-inch poles. The Big Agnes Copper Spur Bikepacking tent also has a different footprint compared to the normal Copper Spur. But really is just the shorter poles. They are also really good for motorcycle touring as well as kayak camping.
data.author: Ronnie Cole

data.text: I love the extra vestibule space in my CopperSpur. It would be great as a backpacking tent too since you could easily stow your packs under them out of the weather.
data.author: Garth Fenton

data.text: Bikepacking tents fit between drop bars on bikes. They are also usually more expensive and a little heavier because they have more pockets for things like helmets etc.
data.author: Andrew Hampton Livingston

data.text: The sticker on the box.
data.author: Aaron Stegmaier

data.text: I use my lightweight tent I could for backpacking
data.author: Brandi Jackson Hodges

data.text: Marketing
data.author: Jonathan Robert

data.text: In my experience backpacking stuff is lighter, to be carried on your back.
data.author: Chris Vela

data.text: Yeah, the shorter poles & stuff sack. To fit drop handlebars if that's where you would carry poles. It's what I went with as mostly as I didn't have a tent already & wanted to carry the poles up front.
data.author: Mike Kehoe

data.text: Slight modifications of the backpacking versions: shorter poles, specialized exterior storage for a helmet, webbing made to attach to a handlebar. The ability to collapse the poles to a shorter length is the biggest selling point. Backpacking tents pack too long to fit between handlebars or inside a pannier. The trade-off is a slight increase in weight (in the range of a few oz), but it makes much less difference when you‚Äôre carrying it on your bike instead of on your back.

data.text: I just bought a tent.
data.author: Trey Freeman

data.text: Yes, we like the smaller pile sections. It's easier to find some where for me to pack it. That being said, this time we didn't buy a bikepacking tent. Our last ones, from two different companies, both had zipper problems and had to be replaced with heavier non-compacting ones mid-trip. An enormous pain and inconvenience. This time we bought Sierra Designs tents. Mid- price and mid- weight- yes. But, also stronger zippers.
data.author: Patricia Roth
